term.name: falsificationism
term.source: From English falsify: to prove or show to be false based on evidence or testimony.
term.def: The view, first expounded by Karl Popper (1902-1994), that a statement or theory has the potential to be true only if it is falsifiable, i.e., only if it describes the types of evidence that could show it to be false. According to falsificationalism, any other statement or theory is outside the realm of scientific investigation and therefore is meaningless.
